hedline.hl2: My Swiss Hotel: Calm, Serene, Efficient

abstract.p: Jan Morris recalls serene light of very Swiss room at Hotel Beau-Rivage Weggis on Lake Lucerne, where he likes to imagine himself on gloomy, drizzly morning at home in Wales; photo (special section, Favorites) (S)

block.p: OFTEN enough when I awake in the morning to the patter of Welsh drizzle on my roof, and reluctantly bestir myself to plod downstairs and make breakfast, I like to imagine that instead I am snugly waiting for room service in one of my favorite hotels. The one most likely to figure in this forlorn fantasy is the Hotel Beau-Rivage Weggis in Switzerland.

It is not a grandiloquent hotel, nor one of those boutique hostelries, but a comfortably bourgeois, very Swiss establishment on the northern shore of Lake Lucerne. I have been stopping off there for years when I drive across Europe, so it is all too easy for me to fancy I am in one of its sunlit lake-view bedrooms instead of groping for the light switch in the morning gloom of Wales.
What brightens up a gloomy Welsh morning? Thoughts of Lake Lucerne.

OFTEN enough when I awake in the morning to the patter of Welsh drizzle on my roof, and reluctantly bestir myself to plod downstairs and make breakfast, I like to imagine that instead I am snugly waiting for room service in one of my favorite hotels. The one most likely to figure in this forlorn fantasy is the Hotel Beau-Rivage Weggis in Switzerland.

It is not a grandiloquent hotel, nor one of those boutique hostelries, but a comfortably bourgeois, very Swiss establishment on the northern shore of Lake Lucerne. I have been stopping off there for years when I drive across Europe, so it is all too easy for me to fancy I am in one of its sunlit lake-view bedrooms instead of groping for the light switch in the morning gloom of Wales.

It is the pale serenity of it all that I imagine -- pale with early sunshine, pale with snowlight from the mountains all around, pale from the glimmering lake, pale with the calm kind efficiency of a classically Swiss hotel. My room, of course, is spotless. In a minute or two, there will be a soft knock on my door and an impeccable young person will tiptoe in to lay my breakfast on the balcony -- coffee, juice, muesli, bread fresh from the bakery and a bowl of cherry jam.
Everything works, naturally, like clockwork. The Beau-Rivage is family-owned and faultlessly professional.

As the waitress withdraws, I wait to hear the discreet thump-thump of the lake steamer which, like clockwork, too, passes several times a day in lordly navigation -- for me, the chief of all the delights of this delightful hotel.
Listen, here it comes now! But no, it's only the farmer's pickup sloshing up our lane to prepare the cows for milking -- my signal, every morning, that it's time to get up and put the kettle on.
Jan Morris's most recent book is ''A Writer's House in Wales.''
